raw_text:
Holmes feted with further honour
 
 Double Olympic champion Kelly Holmes has been voted European Athletics (EAA) woman athlete of 2004 in the governing body's annual poll.
 
 The Briton, made a dame in the New Year Honours List for taking 800m and 1,500m gold, won vital votes from the public, press and EAA member federations. She is only the second British woman to land the title after- Sally Gunnell won for her world 400m hurdles win in 1993. Swedish triple jumper Christian Olsson was voted male athlete of the year. The accolade is the latest in a long list of awards that Holmes has received since her success in Athens. In addition to becoming a dame, she was also named the BBC Sports Personality of the Year in December. Her gutsy victory in the 800m also earned her the International Association of Athletics Federations' award for the best women's performance in the world for 2004. And she scooped two awards at the British Athletics Writers' Association annual dinner in October.
llama3.2:1b: Kelly Holmes has been voted European Athletics woman athlete of 2004 and received another honour, becoming a dame. She also won other awards including BBC Sports Personality of the Year and an award for best women's performance in the world for 2004.
llama3.2:3b: Kelly Holmes voted European Athletics woman athlete of 2004, becoming only second British woman to win the title after Sally Gunnell; Swedish triple jumper Christian Olsson also named male athlete of the year.
gemma2:2b: Kelly Holmes was voted European Athletics (EAA) woman athlete of 2004, becoming the second British woman to receive this honor. She also won Damehood and BBC Sports Personality of the Year.  Her victory in the 800m earned her the IAAF award for best women's performance in the world for 2004.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Holmes became the second British woman to win the European Athletics (EAA) title since 1993 after becoming a dame and being named the BBC Sports Personality of the Year in December. She won two awards including the International Association of Athletics Federations' award for best women's performance in the world for 2004, scooped two more awards at British Athletics Writers' Association annual dinner, and became a dame and named the BBC Sports Personality of the Year in December.
qwen2.5:1.5b: British athlete Kelly Holmes, double Olympic champion and dame recipient, wins European Athletics woman athlete title amid accolades including BBC Sports Personality of the Year and International Association of Athletics Federations award for world's best women's performance in 2004.
qwen2.5:3b: Kelly Holmes, a double Olympic champion, has been voted European Athletics woman athlete of 2004. She is only the second British female to win this title after Sally Gunnell in 1993. Holmes was honored for her victories in the 800m and 1,500m events at the Athens Olympics. She received multiple awards since her success, including becoming a Dame in the New Year Honours List, being named BBC Sports Personality of the Year, and winning the International Association of Athletics Federations' award for best women's performance in 2004.

<think>
Okay, so I need to write a summary of this text about Kelly Holmes. Let me start by reading through it carefully.

The first sentence mentions that Holmes is feted with further honor and that she's been voted as the European Athletics woman athlete of 2004. That's her main achievement right there. Then it says she was made a dame on New Year's honors list after winning 800m and 1500m golds, which must mean she did really well in those events.

She won public votes from the public, press, and EAA member federations. That shows how much support she got from everyone who voted her. The text also says she's only the second British woman to win a title after Sally Gunnell, who won 400m hurdles in 1993. So Holmes is following suit with a new British woman in this race.

Swedish triple jumper Christian Olsson was also voted male athlete of the year. I know triple jumpers are tough, so that's interesting to note. The accolade is her latest award since she won at the Olympics in Athens. So she's been doing well all around since then.

She received several other awards too: named BBC Sports Personality of the Year in December, got the International Association of Athletics Federations award for best women's performance in 2004, and two awards at the British athletics writers' association dinner in October. That shows her multiple recognitions from various organizations.

So putting this together, I need to capture her achievements, her background, her notable wins, and the different awards she received. The summary should highlight that Holmes is a significant figure in athletic history, especially for women, with several high-profile successes and recognition.

I should make sure to include key points like being voted as woman athlete of 2004, winning 800m and 1500m golds, being the second British female winner after Sally Gunnell, triple jump record holder Christian Olsson, receiving multiple awards from EAA, BBC, IAAF, and others.

I also need to ensure that the summary is concise—no extra information, just the main points. So I'll start with Holmes being honored for her achievements in 2004, mention her wins, her position as second British woman, her triple jump record, and all the awards she received from various organizations.
</think>

Kelly Holmes was honored for being voted as the European Athletics (EAA) woman athlete of 2004. She secured victories in the 800m and 1500m, winning public votes from diverse sources including the public, press, and EAA federations. She is the second British woman to win a title after Sally Gunnell's 1993 world 400m hurdles victory. Christian Olsson was also recognized as the male athlete of the year. Holmes was recognized with the IAAF Women's Best Performance award for 2004 and received awards from EAA, BBC Sports Personality of the Year in December, and two awards at the British Athletics Writers' Association dinner in October.
tinyllama:1.1b: In conclusion, Kelly Holmes has been awarded European Athletics (EAA) woman athlete of 2004 with a record-breaking feat in both the 800m and 1500m. She was voted the second year running by the governing body's annual poll, as well as winning two awards at the British Athletics Writers' Association dinner for her impressive performances that year. Holmes' multiple accolades have been recognized internationally and cemented her status as one of the most successful athletes in history.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Holmes, a legendary British athlete and three-time Olympic champion, has been voted European Athletics Woman Athlete of the Year. In an outstanding performance, Kelly Holmes won gold medals in both the women's 800 meters and 1,500 meters at the 2004 European Athletics Championships. This victory was a massive accomplishment for the British athletics team, as it marked her second time on the podium after winning double gold medals at Sally Gunnell's world 400m hurdles triumph in 1993.
phi:2.7b: Kelly Holmes, a double Olympic champion and European Athletics woman athlete of 2004, has been voted European Athletics (EAA) female athlete of 2004 by the governing body. She is only the second Briton to win this title after Sally Gunnell who won for her world 400m hurdles win in 1993.
orca-mini:3b: Kelly Holmes was voted European Athletics (EAA) woman athlete of 2004 after being recognized as the best female athlete in the world by the International Association of Athletics Federations. She won the award for her gold medal-winning performances in the 800m and 1,500m races in Athens, as well as her performance in the hurdles event. She was also named the BBC Sports Personality of the Year in December, received awards from the British Athletics Writers' Association, and was recognized as the best female athlete in the world by the International Association of Athletics Federations.
hermes3:3b: Kelly Holmes won 2004 European Athletics woman athlete of the year.

Swedish triple jumper Christian Olsson won the male athlete of the year award. This accolade is among many awards Holmes has received since her success in Athens, including being named the BBC Sports Personality of the Year and earning the International Association of Athletics Federations' award for best women's performance in 2004.
stablelm2:1.6b: Olympic champion Kelly Holmes receives prestigious European Athletics Woman Athlete of the Year title after securing vital votes from public, press, and EAA member federations. She becomes only the second British woman to win the award after Sally Gunnell, following her victories in Athens, including being named the BBC Sports Personality of the Year in December.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
British Olympic champion Kelly Holmes was named European Athletics (EAA) Woman Athlete of 2004, marking her as the second British woman to receive this honor, following Sally Gunnell in 1993. This recognition came from public, press, and EAA member federations' votes. Holmes won gold in the 800m and 1,500m events at the Athens Olympics, contributing to her dame status in the New Year Honours List for that year.

In addition to this accolade, Holmes was also recognized as BBC Sports Personality of the Year in December 2004 and received the International Association of Athletics Federations' award for the best women's performance globally in 2004 due to her impressive Olympic victory. Furthermore, she took home two awards at the British Athletics Writers' Association annual dinner in October.

Swedish triple jumper Christian Olsson was chosen as Male Athlete of the Year in the same EAA poll.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Kelly Holmes, double Olympic champion, was named European Athletics (EAA) woman athlete of 2004. The Briton, who won gold in the 800m and 1,500m, secured votes from the public, press, and EAA federations. She is only the second British woman to receive the title after Sally Gunnell in 1993. Swedish triple jumper Christian Olsson was named male athlete of the year. Holmes has received numerous accolades, including being made a dame, winning BBC Sports Personality of the Year, and earning the IAAF award for best women's performance in 2004. She also won two awards from the British Athletics Writers' Association.
